articles.headline: Broadcasters Battling for Cable Fees
articles.snippet: Fox is pushing Time Warner Cable to pay about $1 for each subscriber, as broadcasters seek new revenue streams to offset advertising declines.
articles.abstract: Fox is pushing Time Warner Cable to pay about $1 for each subscriber, as broadcasters seek new revenue streams to offset advertising declines.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nearly billion-dollar battle between broadcasters and cable operators over programming fees has gone public.

articles.headline: Emissions Disclosure as a Business Virtue
articles.snippet: A nonprofit tracks emissions and persuades some companies to change policies before governments step in.
articles.abstract: A nonprofit tracks emissions and persuades some companies to change policies before governments step in.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cupping their hands near holes drilled for cable routing, workers at the Boeing Company’s four-acre data processing site near Seattle noticed this year that air used to keep the computers cool was seeping through floor openings.

articles.headline: Ex-Employee Says Seagate Violated Law
articles.snippet: In a court filing, a former employee, Paul A. Galloway, said that Seagate had appropriated hard-drive technology from Convolve for its own products.
articles.abstract: In a court filing, a former employee, Paul A. Galloway, said that Seagate had appropriated hard-drive technology from Convolve for its own products.
articles.lead_paragraph: A decade-long lawsuit pitting a tiny company called Convolve against Seagate Technology has taken an unexpected turn after a whistle-blower claimed that Seagate had appropriated Convolve technology and later destroyed evidence in the case.
articles.byline: By Ashlee Vance and Diana B. Henriques

articles.headline: U.S. Struggles Anew to Ensure Safety as Gaps Are Revealed
articles.snippet: The Department of Homeland Security is struggling to strengthen an aviation security system that it has spent $40 billion rebuilding since 2001.
articles.abstract: The Department of Homeland Security is struggling to strengthen an aviation security system that it has spent $40 billion rebuilding since 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Airline passengers are now increasingly being patted down, and carry-ons are being double-checked since a self-proclaimed terrorist tried to bring down a passenger jet headed to Detroit on Christmas Day. Canine teams are out in force, sniffing for explosives.

articles.headline: To Keep Home Fires Burning, Grab That Boa
articles.snippet: With Operation Bombshell, Army wives learn basics of burlesque to welcome their husbands returning from war.
articles.abstract: With Operation Bombshell, Army wives learn basics of burlesque to welcome their husbands returning from war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATERTOWN, N.Y.  The women arrived on time; they were, after all, Army wives. Gym-class demure in velour sweat pants, cotton T-shirts and dirt-smudged cross trainers, they looked ready for a Pilates workout.

articles.headline: New Slip in Housing Prices Undercuts Fragile Optimism
articles.snippet: Fresh worries about housing came as economic growth for the third quarter was revised down to an annual rate of 2.2 percent from 2.8 percent.
articles.abstract: Fresh worries about housing came as economic growth for the third quarter was revised down to an annual rate of 2.2 percent from 2.8 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just as the economy is finally beginning to strengthen, the real estate market is showing new signs of deterioration.
